name: Apple___Apple_scab
description: Apple scab is a fungal disease that affects apple trees, causing brown or grayish spots on the leaves and fruit. This disease can lead to fruit damage and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis. It spreads through rain, irrigation, and infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid apple scab, use resistant varieties, maintain good ventilation around trees, and ensure the removal and destruction of infected plant debris.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays such as sulfur and lime can be used to control apple scab. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Apple___Black_rot
description: Black rot is a fungal disease that affects apple trees, causing dark spots on the leaves and fruit. This disease can lead to fruit damage and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa. It spreads through rain, irrigation, and infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid black rot, use resistant varieties, maintain good ventilation around trees, and ensure the removal and destruction of infected plant debris.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays such as thiophanate and thiometon can be used to control black rot. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Apple___Cedar_apple_rust
description: Cedar apple rust is a fungal disease that affects apple trees, causing orange growths on the leaves and stems. This disease can lead to leaf damage and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae. It spreads through wind and rain.
prevention: To avoid cedar apple rust, ensure the removal of cedar trees near apple trees, and use resistant varieties.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays such as thiophanate and metalaxyl can be used to control cedar apple rust. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Apple___healthy
description: This category represents healthy apple trees without any detectable diseases.
cause: None
prevention: Maintain overall plant health by providing adequate water, nutrients, and sunlight. Practice good hygiene by removing and disposing of fallen leaves and fruit.
treatment: None

name: Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew
description: Powdery mildew is a fungal disease that affects cherry trees, causing a white layer on the leaves and stems. This disease can lead to leaf damage and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Podosphaera clandestina. It spreads through air and irrigation.
prevention: To avoid powdery mildew, use resistant varieties, maintain good ventilation around trees, and ensure the removal and destruction of infected plant debris.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays such as sulfur can be used to control powdery mildew. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy
description: This category represents healthy cherry trees without any detectable diseases.
cause: None
prevention: Maintain overall plant health by providing adequate water, nutrients, and sunlight. Practice good hygiene by removing and disposing of fallen leaves and fruit.
treatment: None

name: Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_leaf_spot
description: Gray leaf spot, also known as gray rust, is a fungal disease that affects corn plants, causing small square spots with a brown center and dark borders on the leaves. It thrives in warm and moist conditions and can lead to a reduction in photosynthesis and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis. It spreads through seeds and can survive winter in infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid gray leaf spot, implement crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and avoid overhead irrigation. Plant resistant corn varieties if available.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as azoxystrobin, pyraclonil, or trifloxystrobin can help control gray leaf spot. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_
description: Common rust is a fungal disease that affects corn plants, causing small orange spots on the leaves and stems. It thrives in moist and moderate conditions and can lead to a reduction in photosynthesis and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi. It spreads through seeds and can survive winter in infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid common rust, apply fungicides preventively, plant resistant corn varieties, and implement crop rotation.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as fluxapyroxad, prochloraz, or tebuconazole can help control common rust. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight
description: Northern leaf blight is a fungal disease that affects corn plants, causing long, narrow, brown lesions on the leaves. It thrives in moist and moderate conditions and can lead to a reduction in photosynthesis and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Setosphaeria turcica. It spreads through seeds and can survive winter in infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid northern leaf blight, implement crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and avoid overhead irrigation. Plant resistant corn varieties if available.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as benzoxazim, prochloraz, or fluxapyroxad can help control northern leaf blight. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

description: This category represents healthy corn plants without any detectable diseases.

prevention: Maintain overall plant health by providing adequate water, nutrients, and sunlight. Practice good hygiene by removing and disposing of fallen leaves and fruit.

name: Grape___Black_rot
description: Black rot is a fungal disease that affects grapevines, causing raised brown lesions on the fruit and leaves. It thrives in warm and moist conditions and can lead to a reduction in fruit quality and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii. It spreads through rain and can survive winter in infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid black rot, remove and dispose of infected fruit and fallen grape leaves, and apply fungicides preventively.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as mancozeb, myclobutanil, or thiophanate-methyl can help control black rot. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles)
description: Esca (Black Measles) is a fungal disease that affects grapevines, causing damage, swelling, and dwarfing on the branches and shoots. It thrives in warm and moist conditions and can lead to tree death.
cause: Caused by the fungi Phaeoacremonium spp. and Phaeomoniella chlamydospora. It spreads through rain and can survive winter in infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid Esca, prune infected branches and sanitize tools between cuts, and apply fungicides preventively.
treatment: There is no effective treatment for Esca once infection occurs. Preventive practices such as proper pruning and tool sanitation can help reduce disease spread.

name: Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot)
description: Leaf blight is a fungal disease that affects grapevines, causing yellow to brown spots on the leaves and fruit. It thrives in warm and moist conditions and can lead to a reduction in photosynthesis and yield loss.
cause: Caused by the fungus Isariopsis spp. It spreads through rain and can survive winter in infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid leaf blight, remove and destroy infected leaves and fallen fruit, and apply fungicides preventively.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as mancozeb, myclobutanil, or thiophanate-methyl can help control leaf blight. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Grape___healthy
description: This category represents healthy grapevines without any detectable diseases.
cause: None
prevention: Maintain overall tree health by providing adequate water, nutrients, and sunlight. Practice good hygiene by removing and disposing of fallen leaves and fruit.

name: Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening)
description: Huanglongbing (Citrus greening) is a bacterial disease affecting citrus trees, causing yellowing of leaves and abnormal growth stages. It thrives in hot and humid conditions and can lead to tree destruction.
cause: The disease is caused by the bacterium Candidatus Liberibacter spp. It spreads through insects and improper application of chemical pesticides.
prevention: To prevent Huanglongbing, use certified healthy plants, monitor and maintain pest controls, and apply proper fertilization.
treatment: There is no cure for Huanglongbing. Infected trees must be removed to prevent the disease from spreading to other trees.

name: Peach___Bacterial_spot
description: Bacterial spot is a bacterial disease affecting peach trees, causing dark spots on leaves and fruits. It thrives in humid and warm conditions and can lead to reduced fruit quality and yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas arboricola pv. pruni. It spreads through water, insects, and infected plant debris.
prevention: To avoid bacterial spot, plant resistant varieties, use drip irrigation, and plant trees in well-ventilated areas.
treatment: There is no curative treatment for bacterial spot. Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as chlorothalonil and trifloxystrobin or copper compounds can be used early in the season to control infection.

name: Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot
description: Bacterial spot is a bacterial disease affecting sweet pepper plants, causing dark spots on leaves and fruits. It thrives in humid and warm conditions and can lead to reduced fruit quality and yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria. It spreads through water, insects, and infected plant debris.

treatment: There is no curative treatment for bacterial spot. Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as chlorothalonil and trifloxystrobin or copper compounds can be used early in the season to control infection.

name: Potato___Early_blight
description: Early blight is a fungal disease affecting potato plants, causing circular brown spots on leaves. It thrives in humid and warm conditions and can lead to reduced potato yield.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It spreads through infected plant debris, soil, and seeds.
prevention: To avoid early blight, practice crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and avoid overhead irrigation.
treatment: Fungicides containing active ingredients such as chlorothalonil and trifloxystrobin or copper compounds can help control early blight. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Potato___Late_blight
description: Late blight is a fungal disease affecting potato plants, causing dark spots on leaves and stems. It thrives in humid and cool conditions and can lead to reduced potato yield.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Phytophthora infestans. It spreads through rain, irrigation, soil, and seeds.
prevention: To avoid late blight, practice crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and avoid overhead irrigation.
treatment: Fungicides containing active ingredients such as chlorothalonil and trifloxystrobin or copper compounds can help control late blight. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Squash___Powdery_mildew
description: Powdery mildew is a fungal disease affecting squash plants, causing a powdery white layer on leaves and stems. It thrives in moist and moderate conditions and can lead to reduced photosynthesis and yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Podosphaera xanthii. It spreads rapidly in warm and humid conditions.
prevention: To avoid powdery mildew, practice crop rotation, plant squash in dry seasons, and use slow-release fertilization.
treatment: Fungicides containing active ingredients such as sulfur and picarbstrobin or thiophanates can help control powdery mildew. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Tomato___Bacterial_spot
description: Bacterial spot is a bacterial disease affecting tomato plants, causing dark spots on leaves and fruits. It thrives in moist and warm conditions and can lead to reduced fruit quality and yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria. It spreads through water, insects, and infected plant debris.
prevention: To prevent bacterial spot, use certified disease-free plants, plant tomatoes in dry seasons, and use balanced fertilization.
treatment: There is no curative treatment for bacterial spot. Fungicidal sprays can be used early in the season to control infection.

name: Tomato___Early_blight
description: Early blight is a fungal disease affecting tomato plants, causing brown circular spots on the leaves. It thrives in moist and warm conditions and can lead to reduced tomato yield.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. It spreads through infected plant debris, soil, and seeds.
prevention: To avoid early blight, practice crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and avoid overhead watering.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as chlorothalonil and trifloxystrobin or chemomycin can help control early blight. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Tomato___Late_blight
description: Late blight is a fungal disease affecting tomato plants, causing dark spots on leaves and stems. It thrives in moist and cool conditions and can lead to reduced tomato yield.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Phytophthora infestans. It spreads through rain, irrigation, soil, and seeds.
prevention: To avoid late blight, practice crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and avoid overhead watering.
treatment: Fungicidal sprays containing active ingredients such as chlorothalonil and trifloxystrobin or chemomycin can help control late blight. Apply according to label instructions and in coordination with cultural practices.

name: Tomato___Leaf_Mold
description: Leaf mold is a fungal disease affecting tomato plants, causing distortion and drying of the leaves. It thrives in moist and warm conditions and can lead to reduced fruit quality and yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Fulvia fulva. It spreads rapidly in moist and warm conditions.
prevention: To avoid leaf mold, practice crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and plant tomatoes in well-ventilated areas.
treatment: There is no curative treatment for leaf mold. Fungicidal sprays can be used early in the season to control infection.

name: Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot
description: Septoria leaf spot is a fungal disease affecting tomato plants, causing brown circular spots on the leaves. It thrives in moist and moderate conditions and can lead to reduced fruit quality and yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici. It spreads rapidly in moist and moderate conditions.
prevention: To avoid Septoria leaf spot, practice crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and plant tomatoes in well-ventilated areas.
treatment: There is no curative treatment for Septoria leaf spot. Fungicidal sprays can be used early in the season to control infection.

name: Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider_mite
description: Two-spotted spider mite is a pest that affects tomato plants, feeding on plant cells, leading to the appearance of yellow spots on the leaves and their drying.
cause: This pest is caused by the mite Tetranychus urticae.
prevention: To reduce infestation by two-spotted spider mites, regularly monitor for signs of infestation and spray plants with water to reduce mite numbers.
treatment: In cases of severe infestation, insecticides targeted at controlling two-spotted spider mites such as methoprene and sulfur can be used.

name: Tomato___Target_Spot
description: Target spot is a fungal disease affecting tomato plants, causing brown circular spots on the leaves. It thrives in moist and moderate conditions and can lead to reduced fruit quality and yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola. It spreads rapidly in moist and moderate conditions.
prevention: To avoid target spot, practice crop rotation, remove and destroy infected plant debris, and plant tomatoes in well-ventilated areas.
treatment: There is no curative treatment for target spot. Fungicidal sprays can be used early in the season to control infection.

name: Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus
description: Tomato yellow leaf curl virus is a viral disease affecting tomato plants, causing distortion, stunting, yellowing, and curling of the leaves. It spreads through insects and leads to yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by a Begomovirus and is spread by the silverleaf whitefly Bemisia tabaci.
prevention: To avoid tomato yellow leaf curl virus, use healthy certified plants and avoid pest infestations by covering plants or using insecticides.
treatment: There is no direct treatment for tomato yellow leaf curl virus. Insecticides can be used to control virus-carrying insects to reduce disease spread.

name: Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus
description: Tomato mosaic virus is a viral disease affecting tomato plants, causing distortion, stunting, and appearance of yellow spots on the leaves. It spreads through insects and contaminated tools and leads to yield loss.
cause: The disease is caused by a Tobamovirus and spreads through insects and contaminated tools.
prevention: To avoid tomato mosaic virus, use healthy certified plants and avoid pest infestations by covering plants or using insecticides.
treatment: There is no direct treatment for tomato mosaic virus. Insecticides can be used to control virus-carrying insects to reduce disease spread.

cause: None
prevention: Maintain overall plant health by providing adequate water, nutrients, and sunlight. Practice good sanitation by removing and disposing of fallen leaves and fruits.
